distplyr 0.1.0
  • Reference
  • Articles
    • Intro to `distplyr`
    • Step Distributions

    distplyr

    The goal of distplyr is to provide a unified interface for manipulating distributions. The name is inspired by the dplyr package.

    The need for this package arose as I was trying to implement distributional forecasting models. I found that I was home-baking functions like a cdf or quantile function, and spent far too much energy managing and distinguishing between distribution quantities throughout the analysis. This package bundles these all together in a single “distribution” object.

    The distributions3 package is close to what I’ve been looking for, but I wanted to be able to work with any distribution, including non-parametric or semi-parametric ones, and I think in order to do that with distributions3, you’d have to contribute to the package.

    Please note that the ‘distplyr’ project is released with a Contributor Code of Conduct. By contributing to this project, you agree to abide by its terms.

    library(distplyr)
library(magrittr)
library(testthat)

    Usage

    Making a Distribution

    Access a distribution from a parametric family using dst_*() functions. Make a Uniform(2, 3) distribution:

    (my_unif <- dst_unif(2, 3))
#> A Uniform distribution.
#> 
#> Parameters:

    Or, a GPD:

    (my_gpd <- dst_gpd(loc = 7, scale = 1, shape = 0.5))
#> A GPD distribution.
#> 
#> Parameters:

    You can make an empirical distribution from data as well, by making a step distribution:

    (my_step <- stepdst(Sepal.Length, data = iris))
#> Unnamed distribution.
#> 
#> Parameters:

    A degenerate distribution is still valid, and can be specified directly, or as a result of parameter boundaries:

    expect_equal(
    dst_norm(mu = 5, var = 0),
    dst_degen(5)
)

    Evaluating a Distribution

    Let’s use my_gpd from earlier.

    Easy to plot:

    # plot(my_gpd, "cdf")
# plot(my_gpd, "probfn")

    Means are easy to find – no more looking up formulas:

    get_mean(my_gpd)
#> [1] 9

    So are variances, skewnesses, etc:

    get_var(my_gpd)
#> [1] Inf
# median(my_dst)

    Evaluating distribution-related functions, such as cdf, density, etc. is easy:

    eval_cdf(my_gpd, at = 6:10)
#> [1] 0.0000000 0.0000000 0.5555556 0.7500000 0.8400000
eval_probfn(my_gpd, at = 6:10)
#> [1] 0.0000000 1.0000000 0.2962963 0.1250000 0.0640000
eval_hazfn(my_gpd, at = 6:10)
#> [1] 0.0000000 1.0000000 0.6666667 0.5000000 0.4000000

    Generate some data:

    eval_randfn(my_gpd, 10)
#>  [1]  7.191411  7.248137  7.384061  9.034786  7.649470 15.602773  8.037122
#>  [8]  7.895555  7.266341  7.153382

    Or, just get the functions themselves:

    cdf <- get_cdf(my_gpd)
curve(cdf, 6, 10)

    Manipulate distributions

    You can shift_left() or shift_right() (or just shift()), or scale_divide() or scale_multiply().

    # my_dst %>% 
#   shift_left(by = 1) %>% 
#   scale_divide(by = 0.5)

    Graft my_gpd onto my_step, the empirical distribution from earlier:

    my_graft <- my_step %>%
    graft_right(my_gpd, sep_y = 7)
    cdf <- get_cdf(my_graft)
curve(cdf, 4, 9, n = 1001)

    Obtain a mixture distribution:

    # mix(..., probs = ...)

    MLE?

    (maybe for another package)

    # fam <- function(a, b) 
#   dst_unif(a, b) %>% 
#   get_nllh(data = iris$Sepal.Length)
#   
# 
# dist3 %>% 
#   get_nllh(data = ...)
# 
# nllh(~ Sepal.Length, data = iris, families = c("unif", "norm"))
